SubTopics: Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units including km, m, cm; kg, g; lb., oz.; l, ml; hr., min., sec. Within a single system of measurement, express measurements in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement equivalents in a two-column table.
Content: Demarcus worked on his science project for 3 hours. For how many ùó†ùóúùó°ùó®ùóßùóòùó¶ did he work on his project?

Key.Rationale: The student uses the number of minutes in 1 hour.
The student adds 60 plus 3.
The student uses the number of minutes in 2 hours.
The student multiplies 60 times 3.

SubTopics: Compare fractions with different numerators and different denominators while recognizing that comparisons are valid only when the fractions refer to the same whole. Justify the conclusions by using visual fraction models (e.g., tape diagrams and number lines) and by reasoning about the size of the fractions, using benchmark fractions (including whole numbers), or creating common denominato
Content: The table shows the fraction of each project several students have completed.
problems/WIG4M/media/2a.jpg
Which student has completed more of his/her math project than his/her reading project?

Key.Rationale: The student compares 4/5 and 2/8 to 1/2 .
The student thinks the larger fraction has fewer parts of the whole.
The student thinks the larger fraction has more parts of the whole.
The student uses a greater fraction for the reading project than the math project.

SubTopics: Interpret a multiplication equation as a multiplicative comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 x 7 as a statement that 35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.
Content: Catherine is solving the number statement ‚Äú48 is 6 times as many as __.‚Äù What number goes in the blank to solve the number statement?

SubTopics: Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.
Content: Percy cuts out a piece of fabric in the shape shown on the grid. He folds the fabric in half so both halves match. Draw a line across the shape to show where Percy folds the fabric.
problems/WIG4M/media/4a.jpg

SubTopics: Add and subtract fractions, including mixed numbers, with like denominators (e.g., 3/8 + 2/8) and related denominators (e.g., 1/2 +1/4, 1/3 + 1/6) by using visual fraction models (e.g., tape diagrams and number lines), properties of operations, and the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Content: What is 3 1/4 ‚Äì 1 2/4 ?

Key.Rationale: The student subtracts 13/4 minus 6/4 and converts the difference to a mixed number.
The student subtracts the whole numbers and then subtracts the fractions backwards.
The student does not subtract from the whole number when borrowing.
The student adds the fractions.

SubTopics: Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.
Content: A protractor is used to measure angle FGH.
problems/WIG4M/media/6a.jpg
What is the measure of angle FGH?

Key.Rationale: The student reads the protractor from right to left and adds 5 to 40.
The student reads the protractor from right to left and adds 5 to 50.
The student reads the protractor from left to right.
The student reads the protractor from left to right and adds 5 to 140.

SubTopics: Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place and describe the result of the comparison using words and symbols (>, =, and <).
Content: Yuri scored 3,670 points in a video game. Amelia scored three thousand seven hundred forty-five points in the same game. Use <, >, or = to compare Yuri‚Äôs and Amelia‚Äôs scores.

SubTopics: Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1-100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1-100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1-100 is prime or composite.
Content: Peter is listing all the factors of 72. Which factor pair should be included on his list?

Key.Rationale: The student adds 70 and 2 to get 72.
The student multiplies 4 and 18 to get 72.
The student incorrectly multiplies 7 and 9.
The student multiplies 7 and 10 to get 70, and adds 2 from the 12.

SubTopics: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots.
Content: Several cities recorded the amount of rainfall during a recent rainstorm.
problems/WIG4M/media/9a.jpg
What is the total amount of rainfall, in inches, that fell in all of the cities?

Key.Rationale: The student adds the column with the greatest number of marks.
The student adds 1/4 + 1/2 + 3/4 + 1 + 1 1/4
The student adds all the amounts of rainfall from the line plot.
The student uses the number of cities that were recorded in the line plot.

SubTopics: Flexibly and efficiently add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers using strategies or algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Content: What is 3,805 ‚Äì 678?

SubTopics: Generate a number or shape pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the pattern that were not explicit in the rule itself.
Content: Julie creates a number pattern that starts with 3 and uses the rule ‚Äúadd 7.‚Äù Which statement about Julie‚Äôs number pattern is correct?

A.Choice: All of the numbers in the pattern will be odd.

Key.Rationale: The student uses odd numbers only.

B.Choice: All of the numbers in the pattern will be even.

Key.Rationale: The student uses the two odd numbers to create an even number and applies the observation to the entire pattern.

C.Choice: The numbers in the pattern will alternate between odd and even.

Key.Rationale: The student observes the pattern 3, 10, 17, 24, ‚Ä¶

D.Choice: The first number in the pattern will be odd but the rest will be even.

Key.Rationale: The student uses the second number in the pattern as the observation for the entire pattern.

SubTopics: Express a fraction with denominator 10 as an equivalent fraction with denominator 100, and use this technique to add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100.
Content: Write the sum of 43/100 + 2/10 as a fraction.

SubTopics: Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.
Content: Which shape has zero lines of symmetry?

Key.Rationale: The student assumes shapes with diagonal sides have no lines of symmetry.
The student understands the shape does not have a line of symmetry.
The student does not see the horizontal line of symmetry.
The student thinks the shape has too many sides to be able to have any lines of symmetry.

SubTopics: Recognize angle measure as additive. When an angle is decomposed into non-overlapping parts, the angle measure of the whole is the sum of the angle measures of the parts. Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by using an equation with a symbol for the unknown angle measure.
Content: An angle is shown.
problems/WIG4M/media/14a.jpg
The measure of the angle formed by ray 1 and ray 3 is 80¬∞.
Use the numbers, variables, and symbols below the blank lines to make an equation that could be used to find the value of x.

SubTopics: Use place value understanding to generate estimates for real-world problem situations, with multi-digit whole numbers, using strategies such as mental math, benchmark numbers, compatible numbers, and rounding. Assess the reasonableness of their estimates. (e.g., Is my estimate too low or too high? What degree of precision do I need for this situation?)
Content: Jackson‚Äôs hometown has a population of 145,289. What is the population of Jackson‚Äôs hometown when rounded to the nearest thousand?

Key.Rationale: The student rounds down to the nearest thousands place.
The student rounds up to the nearest hundreds place.
The student rounds up to the nearest thousands place.
The student rounds up to the nearest ten thousands place.
